item.title: Ethernet Connects Businesses Throughout Latin America
item.description: In recent years, numerous businesses have opted for Carrier Ethernet services for various connectivity needs, including Dedicated Internet Access (DIA), point-to-point private lines, last-mile access to MPLS networks, and meshed connections linking multiple business locations within the United States. This capability is now expanding globally. For instance, Level 3, a prominent international carrier, received recognition from the Metro Ethernet Forum (MEF) for its services in the Caribbean and Latin America.

item.title: Fiber Optic Ethernet Transport Offers Huge Advantages
item.description: By: John Shepler Data can be moved in many ways. The new top choice is Fiber Optic Ethernet, known as EoF or Ethernet over Fiber, which offers excellent value. What is Fiber Optic Ethernet Transport? When fiber optic lines were first installed, Ethernet wasn’t a factor. The standard was SONET (Synchronous Optical NETworking), designed to carry existing DS1 and DS3 phone calls on fiber. Fiber offered significantly more bandwidth than copper twisted pair, microwave, or coaxial cable.

item.title: The Cloud Needs Low Latency
item.description: By: John Shepler The Economic Appeal of Cloud Computing Opting for cloud services over traditional data centers seems incredibly cost-effective. Instead of large loans and capital investments in servers and infrastructure, businesses can subscribe to a cloud service provider and pay only for the resources they consume. This eliminates the need to predict future business demands and allows for flexibility in scaling resources on-demand. The Allure of Simplicity The solution appears straightforward: forgo establishing a new data center or dismantle your existing one, and lease the necessary resources from a cloud provider.

item.title: Connectivity for Telemedicine and Remote Work
item.description: By: John Shepler The rapid emergence of the Coronavirus pandemic is speeding up existing trends, particularly telemedicine and remote work. Both heavily rely on broadband internet bandwidth. Let’s explore the available connection options. Connecting the User Most remote workers and telemedicine patients connect from home using devices like desktops, smartphones, laptops, or tablets. Home users often prefer cable broadband with speeds of 30 to 100 Mbps, while remote users rely on public WiFi or 4G/5G cellular broadband.

item.title: T1, DS3, EoC or Fiber?
item.description: When you require over a Gigabit of bandwidth, fiber is the only option. But what about less demanding situations, needing between 1 Mbps and 100 Mbps? In this range, twisted pair copper, coaxial cable, and fiber optics all become possibilities. So what is the optimal choice today? The Importance of Bandwidth Choice Choosing the right bandwidth connection might seem crucial, but relax. item.title: Bandwidth for Cloud and On-Premises

Let’s explore the available choices. On-Premises Infrastructure A significant advantage of managing your servers and data center equipment in-house is having control over the on-site network. Your Local Area Network (LAN) likely operates at a minimum speed of 100 to 1000 Mbps. Within the data center, connections might have even higher speeds to facilitate short-distance connections between storage, processing, security devices, and other components.

item.description: By: John Shepler Leased lines have been a popular choice for businesses since they were introduced by telephone companies decades ago. item.title: Fiber Internet Availability and Lower Prices
item.description: By: John Shepler It’s time for businesses to switch from traditional wireline internet to fiber optic service. You might be surprised how accessible and affordable fiber internet has become. Fiber Optic Internet: What’s New? A decade ago, fiber optic internet was only for large corporations due to its high cost. The service, primarily offered by major telephone companies, was limited in availability and very expensive. This has changed drastically. Today, Ethernet has become the most popular fiber optic service, with prices comparable to older T1 or T3 lines while offering significantly more bandwidth.

item.title: 10 Gigabit Ethernet WAN
item.description: By: John Shepler As more business moves online and companies shift their IT to the cloud, the demand for WAN bandwidth continues to rise. These days, even small businesses frequently require reliable dedicated internet and inter-office network bandwidth in the range of 100 Mbps to 1 Gbps. Larger companies, particularly those dealing with tech-heavy products, services, or medical imaging, can easily saturate Gigabit connections, making a transition to 10 Gigabit Ethernet WAN a worthwhile consideration.

item.title: DS1 Bandwidth vs Ethernet
item.description: DS1, commonly called T1, is a popular choice for business internet. This article will explain DS1 and compare it to another popular option: Ethernet over Copper. While the terms are often used synonymously, DS1 and T1 are slightly different. They both come from a set of technical standards created by Bell Labs called the T-carrier system, which was originally a digital replacement for analog phone lines. Though designed for telephones, DS1 and T1 are now widely used for dedicated internet connections and private lines.

item.title: 10 Mbps Is The New T1
item.description: The longstanding leading connectivity solution for businesses, T1 service, is frequently used for dedicated internet connections, point-to-point private lines, and PBX phone trunks. T1 connections are easily accessible, cost-effective, and very dependable. However, their main selling point—fixed bandwidth of 1.5 Mbps—is now a significant drawback. While 1.5 Mbps still satisfies the needs of many small businesses and less tech-dependent companies, this is changing quickly. Professionals in fields like insurance, medicine, video production, and engineering all require strong connections.

item.title: Shopping For High Speed Options
item.description: The landscape of business broadband has undergone significant changes. While options were once limited and expensive, today’s market offers a variety of affordable high-speed solutions. For instance, T1 lines, previously exceeding $1,000, now cost around $300 for most locations and offer speeds of 1.5 Mbps or higher with bonding. An alternative, Ethernet over Copper (EoC), provides 2-3 Mbps at a similar price point and allows for easier scalability compared to T1’s jump to DS3.

item.title: Thirty Carriers, No Waiting

Imagine having access to 30 different business-grade carriers, offering everything from basic phone lines to high-speed internet options like wireless and satellite. Whether you need ISDN PRI lines for your office phone system, MPLS networks to connect multiple locations, or Gigabit Ethernet for high-bandwidth applications like video conferencing, you have options.

item.title: Bandwidth Without Usage Metering

Where Can I Get 10 Gbps Dedicated Internet? 10 Gigabit Ethernet service is now commonly available in most cities due to the widespread adoption of fiber optic infrastructure.

This provider leverages its vast fiber optic network, numerous points of presence, and advanced Ethernet over Copper technology to make Ethernet an even more attractive option for Wide Area Network (WAN) bandwidth. This means Metro Ethernet provides a nearly effortless solution for connecting various locations, effectively unifying them under a single network.

item.title: Ethernet Replacements For SONET
item.description: By: John Shepler High-bandwidth fiber optic Wide Area Networks (WANs) are based on SONET, a decades-old telephone company standard. While dependable, SONET’s high cost is leading to its replacement by Ethernet WAN. The increasing demand for business bandwidth makes Ethernet an attractive option for long-distance connections. Why SONET Was Dominant for So Long SONET (Synchronous Optical Network) emerged from a growing need for increased traffic capacity, specifically for long-distance phone calls.

item.title: 10 Mbps Fiber Offers Future Growth

item.title: Zayo Lights Denver With Expanded Fiber Optic Network Services
item.description: Zayo Group, a prominent fiber optic bandwidth infrastructure provider, is expanding its existing metro fiber network coverage in Denver and Colorado Springs. item.title: T1 Line Attributes
item.description: T1 lines have become the standard connectivity solution for small and medium-sized businesses. They support various uses like dedicated internet connections, private lines, network access, and business phone lines. What makes T1 lines so popular? A T1 line uses one or two twisted pairs of copper telephone wiring installed between a business and the telephone company’s central office. While the local telephone company owns this copper wiring, businesses don’t have to buy T1 service directly from them.

item.title: Find A T1 Line For Your Business
item.description: If you’re unsatisfied with your current internet options like DSL or Cable due to fluctuating speeds, frequent outages, or location limitations, and find Satellite internet’s lag, bandwidth restrictions, and weather-related disruptions unacceptable, there’s a better solution: T1 lines. T1 lines, the gold standard for business wireline services, provide a reliable solution with consistent upload and download speeds, high reliability, quick problem resolution, and widespread availability. They offer secure connections between business locations and digital phone line options for PBX systems, features absent in other digital services.

item.title: T3 Bandwidth And Its Competitors
item.description: When your business outgrows its T1 bandwidth, the next step is often upgrading to T3. But what exactly is T3 bandwidth, and is it always the right choice for businesses seeking more bandwidth? Both T1 and T3 belong to a group of telecommunications standards known as T-Carrier, a technology developed after World War II to replace analog carrier telephony with digital carriers. Carrier telephony allows multiple conversations to travel over a single pair of telephone wires.

item.description: Internet access can be grouped into three main types: consumer broadband for homes, dedicated bandwidth for businesses, and mobile broadband (3G/4G). While mobile broadband caters to both individuals and businesses, fixed wireline connections are generally split between business and consumer use. This distinction exists because of the trade-off between cost and performance. Consumer internet, including home-based businesses, falls under “information services,” not “telecom services.” This means they have less regulation and fewer guarantees for customers.

item.title: Private IP Networks vs The Internet
item.description: By: John Shepler When choosing between private and public business connectivity services, it’s crucial to understand the differences and select the right solution. Private lines, known for their reliability, performance, and high cost, have been essential for businesses. In contrast, the internet has become widely accessible and affordable, offering broadband connectivity from various locations. Businesses often need an internet presence to connect with customers and suppliers. This raises the question of whether using the internet for all business needs is feasible.

item.title: Telephone and Internet for Chain Stores
item.description: Cost-conscious small businesses need reliable communication systems. They can’t risk losing customers due to failed credit card transactions or dropped calls. Businesses with multiple locations also need efficient ways to connect their operations. Integrated T1 offers a solution that addresses these needs while staying budget-friendly. Integrated T1 merges voice and data services onto a single line, combining the reliability of T1 phone lines with the efficiency of T1 internet connections. This approach minimizes costs without sacrificing quality.

item.title: Dedicated vs Shared Internet Access

item.title: Ethernet over Copper Solutions
item.description: Traditional business bandwidth solutions, typically offering low to moderate speeds, have long relied on T1 lines and their bonded counterparts. However, Ethernet over Copper (EoC) solutions are rapidly replacing these older technologies, delivering enhanced bandwidth at a lower cost. We’re focusing on services ranging from 1 to 20 Mbps, encompassing both dedicated point-to-point private lines and dedicated internet connections. Ethernet standards also enable private LAN services, facilitating connections between multiple business locations.
